The fact that there are almost four hundred educational
radio stations in the nation today, and that that
number is increasing, is an important fact for us. It
is part of our responsibility here, to bring to con¬
scious awareness the potential radio broadcasting rep¬
resents for reaching people, and to describe the need
to develop programming access to this important com¬
munications capability.
One of the first considerations is economy. Radio
broadcasting is less expensive, per broadcast hour,
than television could ever become. There is generally
a more flexible programming structure to deal with.
There is usually more time available in radio than
there is with television. These are critical factors.
However, there are certain other problems with radio
that we do not face with television. In radio we are
dealing with a one dimensional (audio) medium. This
